issue.title: Properly round `Duration` instances to milliseconds
issue.body:
Prior to this commit Durations used for delays or timeouts lost their nanosecond granularity when being converted to a millisecond Long value. This effectively meant that delays could resume prior to when they were scheduled to do so.

This commit solves this by rounding a Duration with nanosecond components up to the next largest millisecond.

Closes #3920

comment.body: Please rebase your changes on top of `develop` and set that as the base of the PR. See https://github.com/Kotlin/kotlinx.coroutines/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#submitting-prs

comment.body: Hi! If there's any other desired changes I'm happy to make them.

issue.title: Generalize SharedFlow.onSubscription operator - support more general output flow type
issue.body:
- this can be useful in many scenarios, but in general, it allows one to use type hierarchy instead of composition for type-safe code
 - that is especially nice with sealed class hierarchies

comment.body: Ok, thanks, that also works, and is much nicer. We can consider this topic as closed.

issue.title: Generalize SharedFlow.onSubscription operator - support more general output flow type
issue.body:
- this can be useful in many scenarios, but in general, it allows one to use type hierarchy instead of composition for type-safe code
 - that is especially nice with sealed class hierarchies

comment.body:
Two points:

1. You can also do
```kotlin
        someSharedFlow
            .onSubscription<TopLevel> {
                emit(StreamStart)
            }
```

3. The code you're proposing is *not* fixed by your PR:
```kotlin
        fun <T : R, R> SharedFlow<T>.myOnSubscription(action: suspend FlowCollector<R>.() -> Unit): SharedFlow<R> = TODO()

        val someSharedFlow = MutableSharedFlow<StreamItem>()

        someSharedFlow.myOnSubscription {
            emit(StreamStart)
        }
```

The receiver in the block is still recognized as `FlowCollector<StreamItem>`, leading to a compilation error.

issue.title: Generalize SharedFlow.onSubscription operator - support more general output flow type
issue.body:
- this can be useful in many scenarios, but in general, it allows one to use type hierarchy instead of composition for type-safe code
 - that is especially nice with sealed class hierarchies

comment.body:
Ok, explicit type cast didn't come to my mind. So instead of this code
```
sealed interface TopLevel

data object StreamStart : TopLevel

data class StreamItem(
...
) : TopLevel

val someSharedFlow = MutableSharedFlow<StreamItem>

someSharedFlow
    .onSubscription {
        emit(StreamStart)
    }
```
I can write
```
...
(someSharedFlow as SharedFlow<TopLevel>)
    .onSubscription {
        emit(StreamStart)
    }
```
Thank you for the hint. Anyway, I believe that if the operator would work without explicit cast and it will just smartly cast the output based on emits (similarly to e.g. transform operator), the user experience would be better.

pull_request.title: Generalize SharedFlow.onSubscription operator - support more general output flow type
pull_request.body:
- this can be useful in many scenarios, but in general, it allows one to use type hierarchy instead of composition for type-safe code
 - that is especially nice with sealed class hierarchies

issue.title: Generalize SharedFlow.onSubscription operator - support more general output flow type
issue.body:
- this can be useful in many scenarios, but in general, it allows one to use type hierarchy instead of composition for type-safe code
 - that is especially nice with sealed class hierarchies

comment.body:
This can easily be achieved using type casts where needed:
```kotlin
        val myFlow = MutableStateFlow<Int>(1)
        val result: SharedFlow<Number> = (myFlow as SharedFlow<Number>).onSubscription {
            emit(2)
        }
```

In any case, it's not clear what are these "many scenarios" where this is useful. Having `T` everywhere is strictly more powerful than having `R`, but if you need `R` explicitly, for example, due to a `FlowCollector` type, then `T` should automatically coerce to the proper type. If you have some specific code that's cumbersome to write that would be fixed by your PR, please file an issue.

@@ -0,0 +1,71 @@
+/*
+ * Copyright 2016-2023 JetBrains s.r.o. Use of this source code is governed by the Apache 2.0 license.
+ */
+package kotlinx.coroutines
+
+import kotlin.test.*
+import kotlin.time.*
+import kotlin.time.Duration.Companion.milliseconds
+import kotlin.time.Duration.Companion.nanoseconds
+import kotlin.time.Duration.Companion.seconds
+
+class DurationToMillisTest {
+
+    @Test fun negative_duration_coerced_to_zero_millis() = assertEquals(
+        expected = 0L,
+        actual = (-1).seconds.toDelayMillis(),
+    )
comment.body:
Style: please look at how all the other tests are structured in this library.
* Test names: we use camel case, and also, all test names begin with `test`.
* Indentation is different: `@Test` should be on a separate line, function calls are typically on a single line, etc.
* Explicit parameter names here don't add much and are mostly noise.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,71 @@
+/*
+ * Copyright 2016-2023 JetBrains s.r.o. Use of this source code is governed by the Apache 2.0 license.
+ */
+package kotlinx.coroutines
+
+import kotlin.test.*
+import kotlin.time.*
+import kotlin.time.Duration.Companion.milliseconds
+import kotlin.time.Duration.Companion.nanoseconds
+import kotlin.time.Duration.Companion.seconds
+
+class DurationToMillisTest {
+
+    @Test fun negative_duration_coerced_to_zero_millis() = assertEquals(
+        expected = 0L,
+        actual = (-1).seconds.toDelayMillis(),
+    )
+
+    @Test fun zero_duration_coerced_to_zero_millis() = assertEquals(
+        expected = 0L,
+        actual = 0.seconds.toDelayMillis(),
+    )
+
+    @Test fun one_nanosecond_coerced_to_one_millisecond() = assertEquals(
+        expected = 1L,
+        actual = 1.nanoseconds.toDelayMillis(),
+    )
+
+    @Test fun one_second_coerced_to_1000_milliseconds() = assertEquals(
+        expected = 1_000L,
+        actual = 1.seconds.toDelayMillis(),
+    )
+
+    @Test fun mixed_component_duration_rounded_up_to_next_millisecond() = assertEquals(
+        expected = 999L,
+        actual = (998.milliseconds + 75909.nanoseconds).toDelayMillis(),
+    )
+
+    @Test fun one_extra_nanosecond_rounded_up_to_next_millisecond() = assertEquals(
+        expected = 999L,
+        actual = (998.milliseconds + 1.nanoseconds).toDelayMillis(),
+    )
+
+    @Test fun infinite_duration_coerced_to_Long_MAX_VALUE() = assertEquals(
+        expected = Long.MAX_VALUE,
+        actual = Duration.INFINITE.toDelayMillis(),
+    )
+
+    @Test fun negative_infinite_duration_coerced_to_zero() = assertEquals(
+        expected = 0L,
+        actual = (-Duration.INFINITE).toDelayMillis(),
+    )
+
+    @Test fun nanosecond_off_by_one_infinity_does_not_overflow() = assertEquals(
+        expected = Long.MAX_VALUE / 1_000_000,
+        actual = (Long.MAX_VALUE - 1L).nanoseconds.toDelayMillis(),
+    )
+
+    @Test fun millisecond_off_by_one_infinity_does_not_overflow() = assertEquals(
+        expected = Long.MAX_VALUE, // INFINITY duration.
+        actual = (Long.MAX_VALUE - 1L).milliseconds.toDelayMillis(),
+    )
comment.body: I actually don't think this is correct now that I look at it again. This duration has no nanosecond sub component and therefore shouldn't be rounded.

comment.body:
I agree with @denis-bezrukov:
> `(this + 999999.nanoseconds).inWholeMilliseconds`

seems to be the cleanest and, I suspect, also the most efficient solution available to us without getting access to the internals of `Duration`. Here, in realistic cases, it's just a single addition and a conversion to milliseconds.

issue.title: `delay(Duration)` improperly coerces nanoseconds and microseconds

comment.body:
When merged, #3921 should solve this bug, but it's worth considering that the delegation of `delay(Duration)` to `delay(Long)` is backwards. The [Worker](https://kotlinlang.org/api/latest/jvm/stdlib/kotlin.native.concurrent/-worker/execute-after.html) API supports scheduling execution to the microsecond granularity, for example. 

I don't know if having nanosecond or microsecond granularity has a real use case, so maybe not worth the effort.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -154,8 +154,15 @@ public suspend fun delay(duration: Duration): Unit = delay(duration.toDelayMilli
 internal val CoroutineContext.delay: Delay get() = get(ContinuationInterceptor) as? Delay ?: DefaultDelay
 
 /**
- * Convert this duration to its millisecond value.
- * Positive durations are coerced at least `1`.
+ * Convert this duration to its millisecond value. Durations which have a nanosecond component less than
+ * a single millisecond will be rounded up to the next largest millisecond.
  */
-internal fun Duration.toDelayMillis(): Long =
-    if (this > Duration.ZERO) inWholeMilliseconds.coerceAtLeast(1) else 0
+internal fun Duration.toDelayMillis(): Long {
comment.body:
It will now fail for any large (but finite) number, just because of the precision error when attempting to access `inWholeNanoseconds`

i.e. this one should fail
```
@Test fun large_but_finite() {
    val milliseconds = Long.MAX_VALUE / 10
    assertEquals(
        expected = milliseconds, 
        actual = milliseconds.milliseconds.toDelayMillis(),
    )
}
```
because 
```
Long.MAX_VALUE                | 9223372036854775807
Long.MAX_VALUE/10             | 922337203685477580
In nanos (absolute precision) | 922337203685477580000000 | mod1000000=0
In nanos (coerced to 64bits)  | 9223372036854775807      | mod1000000=775807

```
